loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a nipa roofing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 7000 through NWTF to buy additional nipa roofing to sell.

Elma has been in this business for three years. Elma earns additional income from pig fattening.

Elma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional nipa roofing to sell

loans.name: Merriam

texts.en:
Merriam is 43 years old and married, with six children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Merriam is borrowing PHP 6,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Merriam has been raising pigs for two years and earns additional income from food vending. She is working tirelessly to attain her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Marie Grace

texts.en:
Marie Grace is a married 35-year-old woman with four children who are between the ages of seven and twelve. 

She will use the loan to buy more beans and cooking oil to sell. The profits from the business will be used to provide food for the family.  She is very happy with the loan because it will improve her business.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil and beans to re-sell.

loans.name: Joachim

texts.en: Joachim is a thirty-year-old married man, with five children, living in Fort Portal, Uganda. His main business is transport, along with constructing houses and selling firewood, which has boosted his income. He started the businesses to look after his family and educate his children, as a loving father. He faces the challenge of weather changes. As a hardworking man, he dreams of buying land and establishing a farm for animals. Joachim has applied for a loan to pay workers for cutting his firewood.

loans.use: to pay workers for cutting his firewood.

loans.name: Nona

texts.en:
Nona is a 28-year-old married woman. She lives in the Samtredia district with her husband, two infant daughters and mother-in-law. Nona is a hairdresser and works locally. Her husband  works at the railway station and earns a small monthly income. The income is not enough for the family so Nona decided to start a new business and request a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables her to get a loan of 3100 GEL to build a greenhouse. Nona will purchase the building materials and build a greenhouse to grow vegetables to sell. 

The Start Up program will be a great support for her family. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to build a greenhouse.

loans.name: Gocha

texts.en: Gocha is a 42-year-old married man. He lives with his wife in the Vani district. His wife works at local hospital and gets 200 Gel per month. Gocha owns a plot of agricultural land, where he grows nut trees and sells the harvested nuts among villagers. Gocha is unemployed now and decided to start a taxi business since he owns a car. The start-up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables him to get a loan of 1100 Gel to install gas equipment in his car. After the gas equipment is installed, he will serve local people as a taxi driver and will be able to increase the income of the family. Gocha awaits your support.

loans.use: to install gas equipment in his car and start a taxi business

loans.name: Qurotul

texts.en:
Qurotul is a housewife living in Serang, a semi-urban area about two hours from Jakarta. She is married and has two children; her eldest child is 9 years old, and her youngest child is 1½ years old. Her husband works in a private company. 

Qurotul runs a small stall selling mobile phone airtime credit, snacks, drinks, groceries and drinking water, and she also processes bill payments for her customers. She joined Ruma three years ago because she wanted to generate more income to fulfill her family's needs. 

Currently, she is taking a working capital loan from Kiva to boost her daily business transactions and generate more sales, especially on weekends when sales are higher than on weekdays. For the last three months, she has had around $49-$50 in sales per day just from mobile phone airtime credits and bill-payment service.

As her business continues, Qurotul is planning to add more items in her stall and seek more business opportunities. 

In the photo, Qurotul is standing in front of her stall. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to process more mobile phone airtime credits and bill payment transactions on weekends.

loans.name: Asmat

texts.en:
Asmat is 42 years old and lives with her five children in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband has been running a mobile shop for many years and generates income for his family. Her husband troubleshoots mobile problems and sells accessories, including chargers and data cable, while providing recharge facilities for different networks. 

Due to an increase in the demand for mobile accessories and recharge, he sometimes has to refuse his customers. He does not have savings to further invest in the business, because he spends all of his income on household expenses. Therefore, Asmat requested a loan for her husband so he can buy additional mobile accessories and extra credit for the recharge facility. Asmat thanks Kiva and to its field partner for their honorable support.

loans.use: To buy mobile accessories and extra credit for the recharge facility for a mobile phone shop.

loans.name: Dúo Pamomo Group

texts.es:
DUO PAMOMO 
La señora betzaida de 35 años de edad es madre soltera tiene 3 hijos reside en ciudad peronia actualmente tiene a su cargo una venta de zapatos americanos juntamente con una venta de ropa americana  ella es una persona luchadora a pesar de que hace aproximadamente  2 años falleció su esposos a salido adelante y a ha luchado para que sus hijos tengan un estilo de vida cómodo ella empezó su negocio hace algunos años y le ha ido muy bien el secretos del crecimiento de su negociomás es el no dar crédito porque le permite ver inmediatamente las ganancias de lo invertido, de sus tres hijos uno de ellos estudia y dos aun no pero que si DIOS le permite los podrá ir viendo día con día ella toca las puertas de fape en esta ocasión para solicitar un  crédito para poder invertirlo en un lote de zapatos y así poder aprovechar las ventas que vienen en esta temporada…
texts.en:
"Duo Pamomo" Group

Ms. Betzaida is 35 years old. She is a single mother with three children. She currently lives in the city of Peronia. She is responsable for selling American shoes along with American clothing.

She is a hard worker despite the death of her husband approximately two years ago. She has continued to move forward and has fought hard so that her children can live comfortably. She started her business and few years ago and it is going very well. The secret of growing her business is to not sell on credit because that allows her to immediately receive a return on her investment.

Of her three children, one at school and the other two are not. But, God willing, they will be able to study one day.

She is reaching out to FAPE to request a loan to invest in a batch of shoes. This will allow her to take advantage of the sales demand that exists this season.

loans.use: to purchase shoes secondhand.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 5,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase ingredients like meat, spices, vegetables, etc., for her business.

Susana has been in this business for two years. She earns additional income from buying and selling goats.

Susana has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients like meat, spices, vegetables, etc., for her business.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer, age 40, is married and blessed with three children. She sells bananas in her village and earns a net income of 150 PHP daily. She also sells daily cooked foods in her village to generate additional income. Her profits are usually spent on school expenses for her children and used for additional capital for her food vending business. 

She would like to request a loan in the amount of 10,000 PHP to purchase bananas for resale. She's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that her business will become more profitable.

loans.use: to purchase bananas for resale.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of nine children, Evelyn works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming bananas and corn.  Evelyn is borrowing 9,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more bread, coffee, sugar, etc., for her business.

Evelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money in order to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more bread, coffee, sugar, etc., for her business

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 42 years old and married with six children, three of whom are in school. Marilyn works very hard to provide for them.

Marilyn runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 9,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items for resale, such as shampoo, soft drinks, eggs, bread and chips.

Marilyn has been in this business for ten years.

She would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items for resale, such as shampoo, soft drinks, eggs, bread and chips.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is 31 years old and married with three children. With one child still in school, Alma works very hard to provide for them.

Alma runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like snack foods, candles, canned goods, soft drinks, etc. to sell.

Alma has been in this business for three years, and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, candles, canned goods, soft drinks, etc. 

In the future, Alma would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like snack foods, candles, canned goods, soft drinks, etc. to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a farmer and a mother of three children living in Nyamira, a very rich banana growing area. She has practiced farming for six years; she produces and sells milk, eggs, and bananas.  She also rears rabbits, and sells them in the local market. Her biggest challenge in farming is a lack of sufficient funds. 

Susan chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan to fund her rabbit project because their loans are at a low interest rate, and also because Juhudi supports small scale farmers.

This loan will enable her to purchase more rabbits to sell, and then it will bring in more income and thus help her take care of her children's fees and improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase rabbits.

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita is 43 years old and married with six children.  She works hard to provide for her family. 

She runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her general store.

Amelita has borrowed and paid 10 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for six years, and also earns an additional income from food vending.

Amelita aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Nimunyonje

texts.en:
Nimunyonje is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She has operated a fish selling business for the last three years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the Kshs 50,000, she wants to purchase fish, cooking oil, and firewood for her business. 

She decided to join to acquire financial services for her business.

loans.use: to purchase fish, cooking oil, and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Ananita

texts.en:
Ananita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a personal collection direct selling products business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 8,000 through NWTF to buy additional products from the personal collection to sell for her direct selling personal collection products business.

Ananita has been in this business for one year; she earns more income from a general store.

Ananita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. 

She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional personal collection products to sell

loans.name: Fatin's Group

texts.en:
A young Iraqi woman, Fatin is 23 years old, married and a mother of one child. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Fatin is one of the many Iraqi women who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family.

Fatin learned her skills as a young girl and has turned turn them into a small, home-based business which makes women’s and children’s clothing. It is an ideal and widely accepted way to generate additional income for the family. With three years of experience in this enterprise, she would like to improve it, see it succeed and potentially grow it. Inside her home she has the typical responsibilities of a young wife and mother, and she enjoys doing an extra activity through which she can provide services to other women. 

To make her work easier to manage, Fatin is taking a loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq to buy a new sewing machine and a small generator. Because she lives in an area where electricity is scarce and the power supply is often interrupted, having her own generator will enable her to effectively manage her time and plan her work without having to rely on the power supply.

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby rendering them ineligible to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members guarantee the loan. Groups consist of three to five clients, and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group. 

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for her protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine and a small generator.

loans.name: Socrates Walberto

texts.es:
Walberto tiene 30 años de edad estado civil Unión libre vive con su esposa y con su hijo de 3 años, Vive en el Cantón Ventanas provincia de los Ríos.
La ventanilla se llama SAN NICOLAS, se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto San Nicolás, perteneciente a la parroquia Ricaurte cantón Urdaneta, esta ventanilla se dedica a labores agrícolas y pecuarias.
Walberto se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y arroz desde hace algunos años. Compra sus productos en Ventanas y las vende en el mercado del mismo lugar en el Cantón Urdaneta.
El crédito solicito para la compra de abono, urea, líquidos  fertilizantes para la siembra del maíz y arroz. El préstamo le ayudado para aumentar los ingresos para el consumo de la familia y para invertir. Su sueño es tener dinero para comprar un terreno .
Le gusta trabajar y hacer deporte.
texts.en:
Walberto is 30 years old and is in a common-law marriage. He lives with his wife and his 3-year-old son. He lives in the Cantón Ventanas district in the province of Los Rios.

The communal bank is called "San Nicolas" and is located in the rural community of San Nicolás which belongs to the Ricuarte parish of Cantón Urdaneta. This group works in agriculture and livestock.

Walberto has made a living farming corn and rice for the last few years. He buys his supplies in Ventanas and sells them in a similar market in the Cantón Urdaneta district.

He is requesting a loan to purchase manure, urea, and liquid fertilizers for harvesting corn and rice. The loan will help him increase his income for his family's consumption and to invest. His dream is to have money to purchase a plot of land. He enjoys working and playing sports.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for short-cycle farming.

loans.name: Laurentina

texts.en:
Laurentina is taking a loan of 600 USD to improve her business. She is married. She is running a second hand clothing store that helps her to generate income for her family. She will use the loan to buy merchandise, such as shirts, trousers, shorts, short sleeve shirts and long sleeve shirts, to sell in her store. 

She opened her second hand clothing store in 2010, with her own working capital of 300 USD. Laurentina is a hard working woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy shirts, trousers, shorts, short sleeve shirts and long sleeve shirts.

loans.name: Sobia

texts.en:
Sobia lives in the area of Lahore, Pakistan; she is a new member of BRAC and taking her first loan. She is taking a loan for her husband, who drives an auto rickshaw. He has been driving the auto rickshaw for many years using petrol, which is very costly. Due to the increase in the cost of petrol, he sold his old rickshaw and wants to buy a new CNG (compressed natural gas) rickshaw. 

Even with the combination of their savings and the sales price of the old rickshaw, they are still short the amount needed to buy a new CNG rickshaw.  Therefore, Sobia contacted Kiva’s field partner, BRAC Pakistan. With the loan, her husband will buy a CNG rickshaw so he can minimize fuel expenses and be able to increase his income.

Sobia seems very happy after taking this loan. She thanks Kiva and its field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy a CNG rickshaw to replace a rickshaw that used petrol.

loans.name: Adalgisa

texts.en:
Adalgisa is applying for a loan of $1000 to improve her business. 

She is married and has four children.  She is running a beauty salon business in her house.  She is making a good income from the beauty salon, and she wants to buy more needed items with the loan. 

She is living a town near the main road, so many people come to her beauty salon shop and she is open every day. 

She opened her business in 2009 with her own working capital of $100.

loans.use: To buy materials for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Magda De Los Angeles

texts.es: La señora Magda junto a su esposo ha procreado 4 hijos de los cuales solamente uno está bajo su cargo siendo los de más independientes, Magda  es trabajadora que realiza la actividad de venta de cerdos los cuales destaza y vende por libras en su barrio. Hoy en día solicita el crédito para invertir en su capital de trabajo, comprando mas cerdos.
texts.en: Señora Magda together with her husband has four children. Only one child is dependent on her since the others are adults. Magda is hardworking and makes a living selling pigs, which she butchers and sells by the pound in her village. She is requesting the loan to invest in working capital - to purchase more pigs.

loans.use: to buy pigs.

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.en:
Mavjuda is 46 years old. She lives in a small village in northern Tajikistan with her husband and son. The only source of income for the family is from agricultural activities. Mavjuda has been busy with animal husbandry during the past year. Her husband helps her with managing the business. It is hardly enough to provide food for the family. 

She wants to develop the business but doesn't have money to buy more cattle. This loan will help her to increase the number of cattle, and from the profits to improve her family's living conditions. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to buy cattle to sell

loans.name: Ruhsora

texts.en:
The borrower has been involved in animal husbandry for six years and raises big cattle to sell in a local market. She uses the profits to help cover family expenses. She lives with her family in her own home in a rural area. 

She requests a loan to buy cattle to increase her working capital. Her current profits are  not enough to cover all expenses, so the loan will help her to meet all of the household expenses.

loans.use: to buy cattle to increase her working capital.

loans.name: Mutahira

texts.en: Mutahira is a hard-working woman. She was born in 1970. Mutahira is married and has three children. Her husband is a kind man who tries to help her with her business. He is a taxi driver. The fast-developing modern world makes her children more progressive. Mutahira tries to provide them with a better quality of life. That’s why 12 years ago she began own business sewing national women's dresses. She sews in her house. Thanks to the good service she provides, she has managed to gain many customers. Since she’s had her business, her family’s quality of life has been improving. She wants to develop her business further but she needs to buy a new sewing machine and fabric. She is asking for a loan of 1,500 USD to buy a sewing machine and fabric. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and fabric for increasing working capital

loans.name: Sanobar

texts.en:
Sanobar is 50 years old. She is a widow and has two children. Her children are adults. 

Sanobar has been busy with animal husbandry for more than 15 years. She raises cattle in her farm. She buys cattle, feeds them for some months and sells them in a local market. Sanobar is the main provider for her family. 

Sanobar is ill. She must buy medicine for treatment. She is asking for a loan of 5000 Somoni to buy medicine. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy medicine for treatment

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is a single entrepreneur who sells food storage products in her community to make a living. She earns such a good income from this that she is able to support her family.

She acquired a new loan from GDMPC micro credit to repair her parents' house in order to live comfortably. She wants to improve the general living of the entire family in the future.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is a 52-year-old married woman from Sikatuna, Bohol. She has 6 children, four are adult-age and the youngest are 14 and 18 years old.

She has farmed rice and raised hogs for seven years.  She earns an average income of 2,500 PHP per month. She asks for a loan to buy piglets, feed and fertilizer. 

Teopista has high hopes for the future and will work hard. It is her dream to expand her business and raise more piglets to make a better profit .

loans.use: to buy piglets, feed and fertilizer

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida helps her husband to earn an income by managing their own farm, while her husband works overseas. Loida has farmed for four years and earns enough to meet her daily needs. She asks for a loan to purchase fertilizer to improve the farm. 

She plans to use her revenues to improve the entire farm.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Servillo

texts.en:
Servillo is 57 years old and from the municipality of Sikatuna, Bohol. He is married with four grown children. For 30 years now, he has been in the business of farming rice and raising hogs to support his family. He earns an average income of 8,000 PHP. He is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides and to pay for labor. He continues to work hard so that he can save and buy healthy food for himself and his wife. 

In the future, Servillo hopes to have enough savings to live in comfort.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides and to pay for labor.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en: Merlyn  helps her husband work in their own farm to make a living. They have been growing and harvesting rice and they earn well from this. She successfully repaid her previous loan from GDMPC that she used for fertilization. Currently, she took out another loan to purchase fertilizer for this crop season. Hopefully by expanding her farm, she will earn enough for the better future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie is married with two children. She is 38 years old and lives in Tukuran ZDS.

Josie is a farmer and grows rice to earn a living. She has been doing this for five years. She has requested a loan to buy seed.

Josie has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future Josie hopes to have her own rice mill.

loans.use: to buy seeds

loans.name: Speciose

texts.en: Speciose is 49 years old. She sells local juices and has been in the business for the past ten years. With the loan, she would like to buy more cakes and sodas for resale. With the profits from the business, she will be able to earn more savings.

loans.use: To buy more cakes and sodas for resale.

loans.name: Analina

texts.en:
Analina is 30-years-old and married with four children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Analina is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Analina has been farming rice for four years and also earns additional income from buying and selling vegetables.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nyabahengere Group

texts.en:
Nyabahengere is a Nuru International group of three farmers in Kuria West District in Kenya. The members joined the group to acquire skills and knowledge on improved farming methods. They are able to obtain loans through Nuru to acquire farm inputs. As a group, the members of Nyabahengere collectively guarantee the loan.

Eunice, who is shown raising her hand in the photo, is the chairperson of the group and has been a member of the group since the year 2009. She is 53 years old and is married with five children, three of whom are in college. 

The loan from Kiva will enable Eunice to acquire hybrid seeds and fertilizer, which will enable her to obtain high yields. Just like other members of her group, Eunice will take input loans for one acre. She plans to grow maize on ½ acre and sorghum and millet on ¼ acre each. 

Eunice plans to sell the surplus and join a savings and loaning scheme, so she will save some of the money obtained from selling the surplus. She will then obtain a loan to invest in a business and contribute to paying school fees for her children in college.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet.

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en:
Abdallah is a permanent resident of Ndeijja in Mbarara district. He is married with six children and four dependents (as the father) because they are orphans. He grew up without parents, as they perished in an accident. 

Being pushed by the need to survive and to support his family, he started banana farming on a small scale. This banana plantation is being used as a source of food for the family and income for their survival. 

He is requesting a loan of UGX 2,000,000 to renovate the family house and make some expansion.

Pictured is Abdalla and his wife at the old house to be renovated.

loans.use: to renovate his house.

loans.name: Fig Plus Light Group

texts.en:
This group is a Nuru International Group of six farmers called Fig Plus Light and is based within Kuria West District. The members of the group came together in order to grow socially and economically through agriculture.

Peter (shown in the photo with his hand raised) has been a member of this group for two years. He is 24 years old and married with two children.

Peter plans to buy hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum, and millet in a one acre farm. The harvest will provide food and security for his household. He plans to sell the surplus and invest the money in a business which will increase the family’s income.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum, and millet.

loans.name: Maria Thelma

texts.en:
Maria Thelma, 47, is a married woman with four children, one of whom is still in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Maria Thelma has a food vending business in the Philippines. She requested a 10,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients like sugar, milk and fruit for her business.

Maria Thelma has been in this business for five years. In the future, Maria Thelma would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like sugar, milk and fruit for her business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Maria requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell. 

She has been in this business for 20 years.

In the future, Maria would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Prisca

texts.es:
Prisca esta casada y vive en casa de sus padres en la zona Ernesto Torrez de la ciudad de La Paz. Ella es  de profesión confeccionista.
 
Actualmente trabaja por mas de ocho horas en su casa confeccionando buzos deportivos los cuales los comercializa con ayuda de su hermana, todo a pedido; el esposo recien consiguió trabajo en una Institucion financiera por lo cual su sueldo es mínimo, ella con su actividad ayuda a su esposo con los gastos de manutencion de la familia y puede cubrir sus gastos minimos.

el crédito lo necesita para comprar más material, como telas, cierres, ligas, para seguir confeccionando buzos deportivos los cuales tienen mucha demanda por esta temporada de fin ade año.
 
Es la cuarta vez que solicita crédito en IMPRO y la primera vez en KIVA.
texts.en:
Prisca is married and lives in her parents’ house in the Ernesto Torrez area of the city of La Paz. She is a professional seamstress.

Currently she works more than eight hours a day at home making jogging suits which she sells with her sister’s help. All the sportswear is made to order. Her recent husband obtained work in a financial institution, however his salary is minimal. She, with her business, helps her husband with family expenses and is able to minimally cover her own expenses.

She needs the loan to buy more material, such as fabrics, zippers and elastic so she can continue making jogging suits which are in great demand at this end of year season.

This is the fourth time she has requested funding from IMPRO and the first time from KIVA.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics, zippers and elastic for her business making jogging suits.

loans.name: Liberty

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Liberty works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling fruit. Liberty is borrowing a loan of 30,000 PHP through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, spices, noodles, sugar and coffee for sale in her general store.

Liberty has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items for resale, like shampoo, spices, noodles, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Neliya

texts.en:
Neliya is applying for a loan of 1,000 USD from TRM (Tuba Rai Metin). Neliya is 28 years old. She is married and she has six children. She is running a kiosk general store in front of her house and she will use the loan to buy stocks of merchandise to sell in her store, such as a refrigerator for soft drinks like Fanta, Coca Cola, Sprite and Sagiko, as well as beer, bread, cigarettes, coffee, sugar, salt, milk, eggs, slippers, water and oils. She is making good money from selling merchandise and she wants to apply for a larger loan in the future. 

Neliya lives in a town near a school; her kiosk is located in a strategic place where many people, including students, come to buy items. Her husband is a teacher.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator for soft drinks like Fanta, Coca Cola, Sprite and Sagiko, as well as beer, bread, cigarettes, coffee, sugar, salt, milk, eggs, slippers, water and oils for resale.

loans.name: Edelina

texts.en:
Edelina is 51 years old and married with seven children.

Edelina works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 6,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell in her general store.

Edelina has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 20 years, and also earns additional income from raising livestock.

Edelina aspires to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Pacwa Twimukye Group

texts.en:
Geofrey, age 34, is married with 5 children, ages 12, 10, 7, 5 and 3.  Three of them are in school.

He brews local gin as his major income generating activity, and he has been doing this since 2003 to earn a living.

Geofrey has approached Ugafode for a loan of  UGX.600,000 through his group of Pacwa to buy bananas for brewing more local gin (waragi), since the festive season which brings merry making is approaching and promises to pay after making profits.

His dream is to become one of the leading distributors of the gin in the Kibaale district, since he thinks this will raise his income and help all his children complete a formal education.

His main challenges are price fluctuations of the product and a poor road network.

The gentleman extreme right in a tie is the Ugafode credit officer.

loans.use: To buy bananas for making the local gin

loans.name: Muhiddin

texts.ru: Мухидину из Вахдата 31 год. Он женат. Мухидин хочет начать деятельность животноводства. Несколько лет назад он занимался разведением домашних скотов, но из-за некоторых обстоятельств ему пришлось прекратить свою деятельность. Сейчас он решил снова восстановить свой бизнес. Он начинает с самого нуля. Мухиддин хочет получить кредит на сумму $1000, купить бычков и начать бизнес. Для такой деятельности такая сумма является не большой. Мухиддин хочет постепенно начать и поднимать бизнес. Для Мухиддина кредит очень важен, ведь он дает ему шанс начать бизнес и новые экономические возможности. Мухиддин надеется на Вас.
texts.en: Muhuddin from Vahdat is 31 years old. He is married. He would like to launch a livestock business. Some years ago he used to raise livestock but due to some issues he had to fold. Now he would like to restore his business. He is starting from square one. He would like to obtain a loan in the amount of $1,000 USD, buy some calves and launch his business. This amount is not high for this type of business. Muhiddin would like to develop his business gradually. This loan is very important to Muhiddin because it will give him a chance to launch his business and have new economic opportunities. Muhuddin is counting on you.

loans.use: two buy two heads of cattle.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard used the previous loan to buy tomatoes to sell. He has continued with the same business of selling tomatoes alongside a tea plantation in order to boost his income. 

His main challenges are his stock becoming perishable and price fluctuation. However, he has a vision of building a permanent and residential house. 

Richard has applied for a loan to buy tomatoes to sell.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie, 40, is married with three children and lives in Tukuran ZDS.

Virgie is a farmer who grows rice to earn living. She has been doing this for six years. She has requested a loan to buy fertilizer.

Virgie has been a member of PMPC for two years. in the future, Virgie hopes to have her own rice mill.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 42-years-old. She is a mother of six children. She has been selling cooking oil, rice and sugar. She plans to use the loan to buy more cooking oil, rice and eggs to sale.  The profits from the business will be used to earn more savings.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, rice and eggs to sale.

loans.name: M. Akmal

texts.en:
M. Akmal is a 42-year-old, married man, living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. He is the father of a son and daughter. 

He is very hard-working and honest person. He owns a small restaurant in which he offers types of delicious foods. He offers breakfast, lunch, and dinner to the common people. He has been running this restaurant for many years, generating reasonable income for his family. He cooks delicious food for the restaurant and the people like to eat from his restaurant. 

The condition of his restaurant is not good, scratched walls, low sitting arrangements, a dark room, and there is no electricity available. The customer has to face these problems and they feel hesitation to come inside the restaurant. He does not want to disappoint his valued customers.  

M. Akmal wants to establish his restaurant in the form of a redecorated restaurant. He wants to paint the walls, provide electricity, and buy new plastic furniture and new crockery. Therefore, M. Akmal requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner, BRAC Pakistan, so that he can maintain his restaurant in good condition and it can be attractive.  

M. Akmal thanks Kiva and appreciates the warm support from his supporters.

loans.use: to paint the walls, provide electricity, and to buy new plastic furniture and crockery.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a married man with three children, hailing from a rural area in Mbarara District. He grew up as an orphan because his father died in the national liberation war of 1986. 

Because of the need to survive, Julius started hawking phone accessories in and around Mbarara town. Because of his hard work, the business has grown into a big shop. He has even managed to save some money and he constructed a house.

Julius is requesting a loan of UGX.4,000,000 to complete the house. With the house completed, his family will be comfortably accommodated.

loans.use: to buy materials for completion of his residential house.

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Moussa est un électricien de profession, qui exerce le métier depuis 2001 et qui travaille présentement dans un hôtel de la place à plein temps. Il démarre sa journée à 7h du matin jusqu’à n’importe quel heure. Seulement cela ne l’empêche pas d’exécuter dès fois des chantiers chez des particuliers. Moussa loge dans l’hôtel avec son épouse et leur fille de 2 ans. Il n’a donc pas de charges locatives, ni alimentaire, il est logé et nourrit mais il s’occupe cependant de sa mère qui est au village.
Moussa est un des clients fidèles de la mutuelle car il est à son 6ème crédit : des crédits qui lui ont permis d’acquérir en partie son terrain. Il a comme vœu, de construire ; mais aussi d’avoir sa propre entreprise et de travailler pour son propre compte.
texts.en: Moussa is an electrician, who has been practicing since 2001 and who currently works in a hotel full time. He starts his day at 7am and works until all hours. Only this doesn’t prevent him from doing construction on his own as well. Moussa lives in the hotel with his spouse and their 2-year-old daughter. He thus doesn’t need to pay for rent or food, as he’s housed and fed, but he does take care of his mother who is in the village. Moussa is a faithful client of the cooperative, as he is on his sixth loan: some previous loans have allowed him to buy part of his land.  He wishes to build, but also to have his own company and to work for himself.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, and iron for the framework of the house he's building

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores is 56 years old and married with six children, two of whom are in school. Dolores works very hard to provide for them.

Dolores runs a direct selling business, selling Natasha products in the Philippines, and requested a 9,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional merchandise for resale.

Dolores has been in this business for ten years.

In the future, Dolores would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Isidra

texts.en:
Isidra is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a pig fattening business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 5,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase feed, vaccines and vitamins for her pigs. 

Isidra has been in this business for three years. She earns additional income from buying and selling vegetables.

Isidra has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed, vaccines and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Ma. Delieta

texts.en:
Ma. Delieta works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Ma. Delieta requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTFto purchase additional merchandise, such as noodles, eggs, spices, canned goods and coffee, to sell in her store. 

She has been in this business for 20 years.

In the future, Ma. Delieta  would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise, such as noodles, eggs, spices, canned goods and coffee, to sell in her store.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia is 56 years old and married with nine children. With one child currently in school, Antonia works very hard to provide for them.

Antonia runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock of items like snack foods, laundry soap, canned goods, biscuits, soft drinks, coffee, etc. to sell. Antonia has been in this business for 16 years and sells a variety of items.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her general store business.

In the future, Antonia would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of items like snack foods, laundry soap, canned goods, biscuits, soft drinks, coffee, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en: Florentina is 40 years old and married. She is applying for a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She opened her second-hand store in 2000 with her own working capital of $80. She earns a good income from her business. She will use her loan to buy some stock to keep in her store such as shirts and pants. She is a very hardworking woman and doing business has become her regular activity for the past 13 years. She wants to make her business bigger and improve her living conditions in the future.

loans.use: To buy shirts and pants.

loans.name: Ikhlas' Group

texts.en:
Ikhlas is 29 years old. She is a young Iraqi woman, married, and the mother of one child. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Ikhlas is one of the many Iraqi woman who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family.

Ikhlas has 5 years experience with her small, home-based sewing and tailoring business, and she is happy to be able to both contribute to her family’s needs and to create nice products for her customers. She enjoys making dresses for women and children and would like to improve her services and her work conditions. 

She would like to buy a small generator. She is living an area where electricity is scarce and the power supply is often interrupted, and having her own generator will enable her to really manage her own time and plan her work without having to rely on the power supply. The purchase will make her work easier to manage, better planned, and fitted with her responsibilities. To this end, Ikhlas has decided to take a loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq to be able to pay for the purchase.

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of 3 to 5 clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group.

loans.use: to buy a small generator.

loans.name: Sadia's Group

texts.en:
Sadia is a widow living in Iraq. She is 57 years old and the mother of one child. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Sadia is one of the many Iraqi woman who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate the income needed to meet the financial needs of her family.

She has over 10 years of experience in using her sewing skills, making dresses mostly for women based on orders. Her business activity is based in her home and she is working hard to please her customers and attract new ones with her good reputation. To improve her work conditions and be able to better manage her time she would like to buy a small generator, which will enable her to plan her work and deliver results on time without having to depend on electricity. She is living in an area where electricity is scarce and power supply is often interrupted. To be able to make the purchase she is taking a loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq.

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of 3 to 5 clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group.

loans.use: to buy a small generator for her sewing workshop.

loans.name: Nadoa's Group

texts.en:
Nadoa is a 45-year-old Iraqi woman. She is married and is the mother of 3 children she is raising with her husband. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Nadoa is one of the many Iraqi woman who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family.

She has 10 years experience with the small, home-based sewing business and she happy to have been able to build a nice clientele who respects and appreciates her quality work. Nadoa would like to improve the way she is providing services her clients, specifically she would like to improve the way she organizes her work time. With the city power often being cut in her area, she can only work with her sewing machine when electricity is available. As such, her work is often interrupted making it difficult to meet deadlines and deliver best quality services. She would like to eliminate this reliance on the power supply and buy a small generator, which will enable her to work according to her own timeline. To make the purchase she took a loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq.

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of 3 to 5 clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group. 

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a small generator, which will enable her to work according to her own timeline.

loans.name: Ghufran's Group

texts.en:
Ghufran is an Iraqi mother. She is 36 years old and married, with four children. 

With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Ghufran is one of the many Iraqi woman who work from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family.

She has 12 years' experience with using her sewing skills, making dresses for women and children and small fabric household items based on custom orders. 

It might be surprising to see the number women engaged in this type of income generating activity; as simple and ordinary as it might seem, it is indeed a significant step for stay-at-home mothers to be engaged in such activities. 

And the next step for Ghufran is to improve her work conditions, having recognized the importance of proper time management and quality services being delivered in a timely fashion. Her work has been often interrupted by power cuts in her town, and the unpredictability of the cuts made planning the work even more difficult. 

To avoid these difficulties she would like to buy a small generator. To be able to make the purchase, she took a loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq.

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of three to five clients, and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group. 

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a small generator.

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean is 33 years old and from Sikatuna, Bohol. She is married with three children who are one, three and eight years old. Her husband works as a rice farmer and carpenter. She intends for this loan to help them raise their children.  She has farmed rice and raised hogs for a year. 

She asks for a loan to buy feed, supplements, and fertilizer for her farm.  With the availability of this feed, she will be able to care for her hogs and raise them to be healthy and easier to market. 

Mary Jean is grateful that in spite of looking after her children, she can still work hard at home.

In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed, supplements, and fertilizer.

loans.name: Korotoumou

texts.fr:
Née à Bamako, Madame KOROTOUMOU est âgée de 38 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit  avec son mari et leurs enfants à Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
KOROTOUMOU n’a pas eu la chance de faire de longue étude, ce qui justifie son intérêt pour les activités génératrices de revenus à savoir l’achat et vente de tissus, prêt à porter et autres depuis plusieurs ans. KOROTOUMOU est très sollicitée par ses clients à Koutiala et environs.  Pour augmenter la taille de son activité et satisfaire sa clientèle, elle a décidé de rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il  y a plus de 2 ans. Elle est à son 4ème  prêt individuel, dont les précédents ont été correctement remboursés.  
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle compte 4 colis constitués de tissus et de draps de lit. Elle s’approvisionne au Burkina Faso et à Bamako,  effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala en ambulant, à une clientèle composée de femmes en général.  
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 80.000FCFA, qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement de son prêt, participer aux charges quotidiennes de sa famille et poursuivre son activité avec le reste.
texts.en:
Born in Bamako, Ms. KOROTOUMOU is a 38-years old married mother of four. She lives with her husband and their children in Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). KOROTOUMOU was not lucky enough to have much schooling, thus justifying her interest in revenue-generating businesses, that is, buying and selling fabric, ready-to-wear clothing, and more for several years. KOROTOUMOU is much in demand by her customers in and around Koutiala. 

To expand her business and to satisfy her customers, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso over two years ago. She is on her fourth individual loan. The previous ones were correctly repaid. 

With this new loan, she intends to purchase 4 bundles made up of fabrics and bed sheets. She gets her supplies from Burkina Faso and from Bamako. Sales are made to a customer base composed generally of women in Koutiala City by going door to door. She plans on making a monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that she will use to pay back her loan, help cover day-to-day family expenses, and pursue her work using the rest.

loans.use: to purchase cloth and bed sheets

loans.name: San Ignacio De Colón  (Portoviejo) Group

texts.es:
En  el sector conocido como Los Ángeles en la parroquia Colon  de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen  cada quince días los socios  del Grupo De Crédito San Ignacio De Colon. Los mismos que se dedican a diversas actividades tales como la agricultura o al comercio en general. Ellos hace tiempo atrás unieron sus esfuerzos para poder acceder a los beneficios que presta la institución y con los créditos han mejorado sus negocios y se han ayudado para salir adelante.
Una de las socias de este grupo es la señora Orlanda, tiene 54 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen dos hijos mayores de edad,  uno de ellos aun vive con ella. Su esposo no trabaja por motivos de salud.
Doña Orlanda es una mujer muy trabajadora que siempre le ha gustado salir adelante por sus propios medios y ahora mucho más después de la enfermedad de su marido, el cual no trabaja y al contrario requiere de muchos cuidados, ella desde hace 15 años decidió poner un negocio en su casa en el cual vende los deliciosos encebollados de pescado, negocio que solo abre los viernes, sábado y domingos ya que es cuando más clientela le llega y con los cuales se gana lo suficiente para sacar adelante a su familia, gracias a esto a ellos no les falta el alimento en su mesa ni las medicinas que necesita su marido.
Este crédito es para comprar víveres para preparar sus deliciosos platos. Es socia fundadora del Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos. Sus sueños son que su marido este bien.
texts.en:
The members of the loan group San Ignacio de Colon meet every five days in the sector known as Los Ángeles in the Colon parish in the city of Portoviejo. They earn a living through a diverse group of activities, such as agriculture of general trading.

They long ago joined forces to access the benefits provided by the institution. The loans have improved their businesses and have helped them to succeed.

One of the members of this group is Orlanda, who is 54. She is married and has two adult children from this relationship, one of whom lives with her. Her husband does not work due to his health.

Orlanda is a very hard-working woman who has always enjoyed succeeding on her own, especially now after her husband's sickness. He does not work and on the contrary, requires a lot of care.

She decided 15 years ago to put a business in her house, from which she sells fish stew. Her business is only open Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, as that is when the most customers come. With this, she earns enough to get her family ahead. Thanks to this, they don't lack food on the table, or the medication her husband needs.

This loan is to buy foodstuffs to prepare her delicious dishes. She is a founding member of the loan group and likes it because it helps her by providing loans. Her dream is that her husband is well.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs.

loans.name: Jofalyn

texts.en:
Jofalyn is 26 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. 

Jofalyn is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to purchase additional fertilizer.

Jofalyn has been farming rice for two years, and also earns additional income from buy and sell rice grains.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fertilizer

loans.name: Viviana Marcela

texts.es:
Viviana marcela, esta estudiando enfermería, porque como primera medida, quiere salir adelante y seguir estudiando para prepararse y llegar a ser una buena enfermera.
Por lo tanto quiere esforzarse ya que por el momento tiene la ayuda de los padres, pero quiere el día de mañana poderles devolver lo que están haciendo por ella, ya que es con mucho esfuerzo y cariño.
por lo tanto este es el sueño y por ahora una de las metas que quiere cumplir, gracias al convenio con kiva ella podrá culminar una de las tantas metas que tiene,  para que los padres y los que la conocen estén orgullosos de ella.
Necesita la ayuda, para seguir adelante, cumplir el sueño y colaborar a los padres cuando ya termine y poder trabajar y salir adelante.
texts.en:
Viviana Marcela is studying nursing, which is the first step toward her goal of moving forward.  She wants to continue to study in order to prepare herself and become a good nurse. 

Therefore, she wants to make every effort—she has the help of her parents at the moment, but in the future she wants to repay them for all that they are doing for her with such effort and affection.  

This is her dream, and one of the goals that she wants to achieve for now—one of many goals that she will be able to fulfill, thanks to the agreement with Kiva, so that her parents and those who know her will be proud. 

She needs the help in order to continue making progress toward fulfilling her dream—to help her parents when she has finished, and be able to work and move forward.

loans.use: to pay tuition for one semester.

loans.name: Mumtaz's Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz is 35 years old; she is a responsible mother living happily in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. This is her third loan with the BRAC; she is a longtime member; she has been taking loans according to the needs of her family.

She belongs to a poor family and it is very difficult for her to fulfill all the household expenses at low earnings. Her husband has been changing the nature of his business according to the weather; he sells vegetables in the summer season and fish in the winter season. Nowadays, the winter season is going on and this season he does not have enough money to buy fish because the prices of fish have inflated since last year. 

Therefore, Mumtaz requested a loan for her husband, so he can buy various kinds of fish to carry on his business. She is very impressed with this honorable support. She thanks Kiva and the field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

Note: Mumtaz is wearing a green shawl in the given picture.

loans.use: to buy various kinds of fish to sell.

loans.name: Kuinyunyi B Group

texts.en:
Kuinyunyi B is a Nuru International Group of two farmers in Kuria West District in Kenya. The members joined the group to acquire skills and knowledge of improved farming methods. They are able to obtain loans through Nuru to acquire farm supplies. The group members of Kuinyunyi B collectively guarantee the loan.

Samson (pictured with his hand raised) is a representative of the group. He is 29 years old and married with four children (three go to school). He has been a member of this group since 2012.

The loan will enable him to obtain hybrid seeds and fertilizer which he believes will increase his farm's yield. Samson will take input loans for one acre. He will grow maize in 1/2 acre, sorghum and millet in a ¼ acre each. He will grow food for his household, sell the surplus, and  pay his children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married mother of six children from Ubay, Bohol. She has been engaged in a fishing business with her husband for several years now. This is the source of their income. 

Judith is requesting a loan to buy fishing nets, lead weights, hooks, and other fishing materials. With this loan her husband will be able to improve his catch, giving them more fish to sell in the market.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets, lead weights, hooks, and other fishing materials.

loans.name: Suleyma Benneth

texts.es:
Suleyma, con el crédito comprara variedad de ropa como pantalones, camisas, blusas, faldas, ropa interior y trajes para niños y niñas, lo que ayudara a tener un negocio debidamente surtido para la época navideña.
Con el crédito que se le dio antes ella compro la mercadería necesaria para fortalecer el negocio con lo que mejor sus ventas incremento sus ingresos y su familia goza de un mejor estilo de vida.
texts.en:
With this loan, Suleyma will buy a variety of clothes such as pants, shirts, blouses, skirts, underwear, and clothing for children. This will help her to have a well-stocked business for the Christmas season.

With her previous loan, she bought the merchandise necessary to strengthen her business and increase her sales and her income. This brought a better quality of life to her family.

loans.use: to buy a variety of clothes such as pants, shirts, blouses, skirts, underwear, and clothing for children.

loans.name: Paradi De Dorvil Group

texts.fr:
Yvonie est le coordinatrice de son groupe Paradi de Dolval. Elle est marié mais elle a 3 enfants. Elle habite dans la ville de Ouanaminthe d’Haiti où de l’éléctricité est rare et de l’eau est très limitée. Yvonie a dirigé son business pendant les 5 dernières années. 

Yvonie voudrait utiliser cet emprunt pour investir dans l’achat du cosmetiques et accessoires. Elle espère que cet emprunt l’aidera à agrandir son business. Des autres membres de Paradi de Dolval ont besoin d’un emprunt pour tels commerces comme vendre du charbon, du riz et du poisson. Yvonie dit que son défi principal est manque d’acheteur constant.
texts.en: Yvonie is the coordinator of her group Paradi de Dolval. She is married and has three children. She lives in the city of Ouanaminthe in Haiti, where electricity is rare and water is very limited. Yvonie has been managing her business for the last five years. Yvonie would like to use this loan to invest in buying some cosmetics and accessories. She hopes this loan will help her to grow her business. Some other members of Paradi de Dolval need a loan for businesses such as selling charcoal, rice, and fish. Yvonie says her biggest challenge is her lack of constant customers.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics, shoes, clothing, etc.

loans.name: Wend Pagnangde Ghislain

texts.fr:
Mr W. GHISLAIN est un étudiant en classe de Master II à l’ESTPO. Il est célibataire sans enfant.
Il est à l’ESTPO depuis 05ans.
Mr veut financer ses études supérieures à l’ESTPO.
Il ambitionne obtenir son diplôme d’ingénieur de conception en génie civil.
texts.en: Mr. W. Ghislain is a second-cycle Master’s student at ESTPO. He is single and has no children. He has been at ESTPO for five years. Mr. W. Ghislain wants to finance his higher education at ESTPO. He strives to get his degree in civil design engineering.

loans.use: to finance his higher education at ESTPO

loans.name: N. Philippe

texts.fr:
Mr NONGWENDE PHILIPPE est un étudiant en classe de Master II à l’ESTPO. Il est célibataire sans enfant.
Il est à l’ESTPO depuis 05ans.
Mr veut financer ses études supérieures à l’ESTPO.
Il ambitionne obtenir son diplôme d’ingénieur de conception en génie civil pour se lancer dans la vie professionnelle.
texts.en: Mr. Nongwende Philippe is a second-cycle Master’s student at ESTPO. He is single and has no children. He has been at ESTPO for five years. Mr. Nongwende Philippe wants to finance his higher education at ESTPO. He strives to get his degree in civil design engineering to launch his profession.

loans.use: to finance his higher education at ESTPO.

loans.name: Mahamadi

texts.fr:
Mr MAHAMADI est un étudiant en classe de Master II à l’ESTPO. Il est célibataire sans enfant.
Il est à l’ESTPO depuis 05ans.
Mr veut financer ses études supérieures à l’ESTPO.
Il ambitionne se marié et avoir une famille.
texts.en: Mr. MAHAMADI is a second-cycle Master’s student at ESTPO. He is single and has no children. He has been at ESTPO for five years. Mr. MAHAMADI Philippe wants to finance his higher education at ESTPO. He hopes to get married and have a family.

loans.use: to finance his higher education at ESTPO.

loans.name: Lanita

texts.en:
An avid artist by trade, Lanita discovered her passion for photography while earning her Associate’s degree at San Diego City College. While walking to class every morning, Lanita began to appreciate the unique artistic value of the eucalyptus trees that populate the area. Using her 35mm camera, she started shooting photos and was surprised at the quality of her shots. Encouraged by friends and family, she found a local printer to print her photos on high-quality photo paper at low cost, and mounted her photos on professional matting. 

She began selling her photos at local farmers’ markets and art expos and again was surprised by the interest customers had in her work. Unsure of how to officially start up her fledgling business, she turned to local microlender Accion for help.  She signed up for the Accion Academy for Entrepreneurial Success, an eight-week course that teaches students the essentials of starting a business. Upon graduation, students had an opportunity to receive a Kiva loan for up to $5,000 to get their business started.

Going through the program, Lanita gained the valuable insight and encouragement needed to turn her hobby into a full-blown business. She is more determined than ever to sell her artwork and expand her business.

In addition to paying for printing and material costs, Lanita’s $1,500 Kiva loan will enable her to build a website to host her pieces for sale online. She hopes that her business will allow her to one day purchase a home for her family.

Going forward, Lanita is open to expanding into other media in which she has experience, including sculpture, drawing and painting. 

“I get tremendous satisfaction from my art,” she says. “Art is very fulfilling personally.”

loans.use: to pay for printing and material costs and to build a website.

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.en:
The members of this group have asked to remain anonymous but are ready to share their stories with Kiva. The lead member of this group is a 38-year-old Iraqi woman. She is single and is living with her family. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, she is one of the many Iraqi women who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family.

She started her home-based, small income generating activity approximately 10 years ago and she would like to improve her performance and efficiency. She is currently working with an old sewing machine that she would like to replace with a new one. She would also like to improve her time management and buy a small generator to be able to work even during the hours of the day when there are power cuts in her town. These power cuts happen frequently and often interrupt the work she has planned to do. To avoid such interruptions and be able to make the purchase she took a loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq.

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of 3 to 5 clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group. 

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a small generator to be able to work even during the hours of the day when there are power cuts in her town.

loans.name: Afraah's Group

texts.en:
Afraah is a 35-year-old Iraqi widow. Since the death of her husband she is raising their 3 children alone, with the much needed and appreciated help from her family. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Afraah is one of the many Iraqi women who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate the income needed to meet the financial needs of the family.

She has been sitting by the sewing machine for 10 years now and has managed to perfect her skills and attract many customers interested in having dresses made for them or their children. Afraah appreciates the business of her customers and would like to continuously provide them with quality services from her home based workshop. She would like to improve her work conditions and increase her productivity, specifically focusing on her time management. It has been difficult to keep deadlines and work as she would have liked to due to the frequent power cuts and interruptions to the quality of the electricity. These unplanned and unforeseen interruptions have the general tendency to come at the worst time, putting orders and all work on hold. To avoid this she would like to buy a small generator and a new sewing machine. To be able to make these purchases she took a loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq.

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of 3 to 5 clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group. 

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a small generator and a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Sanaa's Group

texts.en:
Sanaa is a mother of six children. She is a 47-year-old, married Iraqi woman. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Sanaa is one of the many Iraqi woman who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family.

She has 10 years experience with the small, home-based sewing and tailoring activity. Sanaa has managed to perfect her skills and attract many customers interested in having dresses made for them or their children. Sanaa appreciates the business of her customers and would like to continuously provide them with quality services from her home based workshop. She would like to improve her work conditions and increase her productivity specifically focusing on her time management. It has been difficult to keep deadlines and work as she would have liked to due to the frequent power cuts and interruptions to the quality of the electricity. These unplanned and unforeseen interruptions have the general tendency to come at the worst time, putting orders and all work on hold. To avoid this she would like to buy a small generator and a new sewing machine. To be able to make these purchases she took a loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq.

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of 3 to 5 clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group. 

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a small generator and a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Risper

texts.en:
Risper lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in south-western Kenya and borders onto Lake Victoria, the second-largest lake in the world. Populations are dense close to the lake, where many individuals make their living from fishing and a few work in the small but slowly growing tourism industry. A popular tourist attraction in Homa Bay county is Ruma National Park, a game reserve that is home to the rare roan antelope, a shy species distantly related to the reticulated giraffe. Most people in Homa Bay make their living from farming, and the rolling hills of the area are dotted with fields and fruit tree plantations.

Risper is married and has eight children. Her husband is a small businessman while she is undertaking farming. She has been farming for thirty years now and she is currently farming maize, beans, watermelon, and bananas. She is looking forward to beekeeping because it is an enterprise that is easy to manage.

This is Risper’s first loan with Honey Care and she intends to use the proceeds from her beehives to pay school fees for her children and to start a small business. Risper’s hope for the future is to expand her beehive project and to change her lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Sidiki

texts.fr:
Mr Sidiki est âgé de 49 ans, marié à une femme, il est père de  7 enfants et loge dans la ville de Koutiala  avec sa famille. 
Sidiki a prématurément abandonné l’école et s’intéressa aux activités de revenus depuis son enfance auprès de ses frères. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, il s’est basé sur  l’achat-vente de poissons fumés.  Pour  pouvoir augmenter son fonds de commerce et renforcer sa capacité de vente, il décida de rejoindre l‘institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de 5 ans. Il est à son 6ème prêt  individuel dont les précédents ont été bien remboursés. Il compte acheter 10 paniers de poissons fumés  à Korientzé  (Région de Mopti) auprès des  pêcheurs d’ethnie  Bozo et Somonô et effectue sa vente au marché poisson à une clientèle mixte au comptant et à crédit. 
Avec ce financement il compte  réaliser un profit de 100.000FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera pour  le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, satisfaire les besoins  de sa  famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Sidiki is 49 years old, married, and the father of seven. He lives in Koutiala City with his family. Sidiki dropped out of school early and became interested in revenue-generating businesses since he was very young, along side his brothers. After having run several business without success, he made it buying and selling smoked fish. 

To be able to increase his capital and to bolster his selling capacity, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso over five years ago. He is on his sixth individual loan. The previous ones were indeed paid back. He intends to purchase 10 baskets of smoked fish in Korientzé (Région de Mopti) from ethnic Bozo and Somonô fishermen. Sales are made in cash or on credit to a mixed customer base at the fish market. 

With this financing, he plans on making a profit of 100,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to pay the Soro Yiriwaso loan interest and meet family needs. The rest will be invested in his business.

loans.use: to purchase smoked fish

loans.name: Aida Magdalena

texts.es:
En  el sector conocido como Estancia Vieja en la parroquia Colon  de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen cada quince días las socias  del Grupo De Crédito Estancia Vieja. Lugar de gente humilde y dedicada a la agricultura y al comercio en general.
En este lugar vive la señora Aida, tiene 50 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cinco hijos,  cuatro mayores de edad y el menor de 15 años que  estudia en colegio, dos de ellos aun viven con ella. Su esposo es guardián.
Doña Aida es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos y con esto poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar se dedica a la venta de ropa, perfumes, bisutería y  accesorios para damas, ella se desplaza los fines de semana y en temporadas de ferias a otros cantones donde instala un pequeño puesto para vender sus productos, tiene más de 7 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.
Este crédito es para comprar ropa, perfumes, bisutería y accesorios para damas. Esta desde el inicio  en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque con los créditos puede financiar su negocio. Su sueño es tener un carro para realizar sus ventas.
texts.en:
In the area known as Estancia Vieja in Colon Parish in the city of Portoviejo, the members of the "Estancia Vieja" communal bank meet every fortnight. This place has humble people who work in agriculture and commerce. 

Aida lives here. She is 50 years old, is married and has five children from this relationship. Four of them are adults and the youngest, 15 years old, studies in Secondary School. Two of them still live with her. Her husband is a caretaker. Aida is a housewife who in order to make her own money and to help her husband with the household expenses, sells clothing, perfume, jewellery and accessories for women. On weekends and market days she goes to other cantons and sets up a small stand to sell her products. She has been doing this for more than 7 years and things are going well for her. 

This loan is to buy clothing, perfumes, jewellery and accessories for women. She has been a member of the communal bank since it's inception and she likes it as she can finance her business through it. Her dream is to have a vehicle to use to make her sales.

loans.use: to buy clothing, perfumes, jewellery and accessories for women.

loans.name: Nellie

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, two of whom in school, Nellie works hard to support her family. She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening.
